process_steps.name: 01 | PRODUCTION PLANNING & SCHEDULING PROCESS
process_steps.step_description:
This step focuses on using an integrated data model to comprehensively plan, simulate, and schedule the entire manufacturing process. The goal is to achieve fast time-to-market and ensure a reliable supply by optimizing resource allocation (materials, equipment, personnel), managing capacities, and reacting efficiently to changes across the product lifecycle, from launch to routine production.

Production planning and scheduling involve orchestrating the supply of pharmaceuticals to meet forecasted demand with efficient use of resources. It is a technical process of allocating materials, equipment capacity, and labor to production activities over time, ensuring alignment with market needs and regulatory constraints. Planners must account for complex variables like batch cycle times, equipment availability, and lead times, while optimizing throughput and ensuring timely delivery. This step sets the stage for manufacturing by creating a feasible master production schedule and batch campaign plan that maximizes efficiency without compromising quality.
process_steps.raw_content:
TECHNOLOGIES:
Modern pharmaceutical planning leverages enterprise systems and digital tools. ERP platforms (such as SAP S/4HANA with production planning modules) handle master data and materials planning, while specialized Advanced Planning and Scheduling (APS) tools optimize the sequence of production. Manufacturing Execution Systems (MES) are integrated to ensure the schedule on paper translates to execution on the shop floor. Organizations are also adopting AI-driven planning engines: AI and machine learning can crunch historical production data and constraints to recommend optimal schedules, improving responsiveness. For instance, adopting automated, AI-supported scheduling has been shown to increase efficiency and accommodate a higher mix of products by handling the complex constraints better. Technologies like digital twins and simulation software (e.g., ProModel or AnyLogic) allow planners to visualize and test production scenarios before implementation. These tools, combined with real-time data from MES and IoT sensors (for equipment status), enable dynamic rescheduling and agile adjustments to the plan.

DIFFERENCES:
There are important nuances between small-molecule (chemical) and biologics manufacturing in planning. Small-molecule production often involves shorter, more discrete batch operations and sometimes continuous processes, which can be scheduled with relatively more flexibility. Biological production, on the other hand, typically has longer lead times (a cell culture run can take weeks) and stricter timing — once a fermentation starts, it must complete, and inoculations must be done on schedule to keep cells viable. Biotech facilities may plan campaigns (multiple consecutive batches of the same product) to minimize downtime from cleaning, whereas chemical API plants might switch products more frequently if cleaning is easier. Biologics also introduce variability (living organisms can cause batch yields to fluctuate), so planners often build in buffers and closely monitor batch progress. For example, a sudden drop in cell culture productivity could force replanning of downstream purification schedules. In contrast, small molecule synthesis is more deterministic once raw materials are secured, though multi-step syntheses require coordinating steps (often in different equipment) carefully. Another difference is inventory: small molecules (especially tablets/capsules) can sometimes be stockpiled, allowing more smoothing of production, whereas many biologics have limited shelf-life and must be made closer to demand. Thus, planning for biologics emphasizes flexible, modular production units (often single-use bioreactors) to scale up or down quickly. Overall, both domains demand high coordination, but biologics planning tends to be more constrained by process biology and sterility requirements, making advanced planning tools and scenario analysis particularly valuable.

EXAMPLES:
As a case in point, a major biotech manufacturer struggling to meet demand discovered through simulation and Theory of Constraints analysis that reordering production steps and exploiting hidden capacity could avoid a $1.2B facility expansion. By tweaking their schedule, they gained an extra $25 million in monthly revenue from two additional lots. Another example is the industry’s move toward smaller, flexible production lines: using single-use technologies and modular facilities, companies can re-schedule different products with minimal downtime, which was crucial during the COVID-19 pandemic when manufacturing had to pivot quickly. Leading pharma companies also use integrated SAP and MES systems to link planning with execution – for example, when a batch is delayed in MES, the ERP schedule is automatically updated to inform planners and adjust downstream activities. Overall, the integration of advanced planning software, data analytics, and cross-functional collaboration in scheduling exemplifies how pharma is ensuring reliable supply in both small-molecule and biotech operations.
process_steps.vision_statement: We use an integrated data model to plan, simulate and schedule the manufacturing process to achieve fast time-to-market and reliable supply.
process_steps.interfaces_text:
Supply Chain Management (SCM): Receives global SCM information (demand forecasts, production plans) as a prior process; interacts for replenishment planning, material availability, and MRP.
Maintenance: Integrated planning of maintenance activities.
Engineering (GFE): Planning for new buildings/facilities (plant modeling), equipment availability.
Quality (QC/QA): Planning for cleaning validation, calibration.
IT & GBS: For planning tool implementation, data integration, and standardized planning processes.
Innovation Unit Development (IU Dev): For plant modeling and simulation for new product introductions and transfers.
process_steps.what_is_actually_done:
Performing operations planning (material, equipment, personnel), capacity planning (including test and tech validation), day-to-day planning, and integrated planning for maintenance, calibration, and changeovers. Simulating various production scenarios, scheduling production runs, and optimizing schedules considering material and equipment availability, capacity constraints, and required times. This includes re-planning due to contingencies and managing campaign planning (number of batches), shift planning, and launch planning. Utilizing a centralized planning tool (or tools like SAP APO, OR-Soft) that integrates data from various disciplines (SCM, Manufacturing, Engineering, CPT, Cleaning Validation) and production systems. This includes managing manufacturing lead times, Bills of Material (BOM), and equipment/system availability. Potentially using AI for demand forecasting to optimize production and warehousing, and analyzing historical production times for predictive planning. Aims for setup-optimized production planning. Simulating new plant layouts and operations to optimize building and facility utilization, supporting transfers and launches by modeling processes with attributes like parameters, equipment data, timelines, and capacity (M02).


In practice, planners use sales forecasts and inventory targets to determine how many batches of each product to produce in a given horizon (e.g., monthly or quarterly). They then break this into a detailed schedule, sequencing production runs on specific lines or reactors. Concrete actions include: ensuring raw materials will arrive on time, reserving clean equipment, and scheduling operators. Advanced planning systems (often integrated in ERP like SAP) generate production orders, which are then refined with finite scheduling tools to avoid conflicts. Scenario planning and simulation are used to test different schedules; for example, one biotech facility used discrete-event simulation combined with lean methods to identify bottlenecks, allowing them to add two extra batches per month without new equipment. Throughout, the plan is continuously adjusted for changes (e.g., rush orders or batch failures), requiring close coordination between production, quality, and supply chain teams.
process_steps.pain_points:
Decentralized planning in multiple Excel sheets; lack of a single, integrated tool.
Slow and inefficient re-planning after production changes or unforeseen events.
Manual cross-checks required for maintenance, production, and material availability.
Difficulties in scenario planning and simulation to check possible outcomes quickly.
Forecast data not directly integrated into planning systems.
Manual effort in transferring SCM's high-level plan to local detailed plans.
Complex planning due to diverse products with different process/equipment requirements.
Lack of a central tool for detailed shop-floor scheduling (Feinplanung).
Inadequate tools for managing changeover data and optimizing changeover sequences.
Missing central database for supplier material qualification.
Planning processes are not standardized or automatically networked with SCM.
High manual effort in risk analysis for aseptic facilities (related to plant modeling).

process_steps.name: 02 | MANUFACTURING PROCESSES
process_steps.step_description: This step encompasses the actual drug production operations on the factory floor – the sequence of unit processes that convert raw inputs into finished pharmaceutical products under strict GMP (Good Manufacturing Practice) conditions. It includes all chemical or biological processing stages as well as formulation and filling/packaging of the final dosage form. Technically, manufacturing processes in pharma are highly regimented and recipe-driven: each batch follows a detailed batch record outlining every parameter and step to ensure consistency and quality. The processes must be validated and operate within defined critical parameters to ensure that the product meets its quality attributes. Whether synthesizing a small-molecule API in a reactor or cultivating cells in a bioreactor, the focus is on controlling the process to yield a safe, pure product.
process_steps.raw_content:
TECHNOLOGIES:
Pharmaceutical manufacturing is supported by a suite of advanced technologies to ensure control and quality. Process Analytical Technology (PAT) is widely implemented: sensors and analyzers (e.g., NIR spectroscopy, Raman probes) provide real-time measurements of critical variables like concentration, moisture, or metabolite levels, enabling immediate adjustments. Automation systems (PLC/SCADA or DCS in large plants) run the equipment with recipe control – for example, executing a time-temperature profile in a reactor or controlling nutrient feed rates in a bioreactor. Manufacturing Execution Systems (MES) provide electronic batch records and guide operators through each step, enforcing checks and capturing data (which improves data integrity and compliance). Quality by Design (QbD) principles are applied so that processes are developed with a deep understanding of how inputs and process parameters affect product quality; this often involves designing experiments and building multivariate models of the process. Modern facilities are also adopting continuous manufacturing for small molecules, where appropriate. In continuous processes, rather than discrete batches, material flows through integrated unit operations continuously; this requires robust automation and PAT for real-time quality assurance. Notably, FDA has approved a number of continuous production lines – by late 2021, about 10 drugs had been approved with continuous manufacturing, mostly small-molecule, and even the first continuous biologics process was approved in 2020. This highlights how technology is bridging to ensure consistent product quality. Other tools like digital twins of processes, predictive control algorithms, and robotic handling systems (for instance, robotic arms in sterile filling isolators) are increasingly employed to enhance precision and reduce human error.

DIFFERENCES:
Chemical and biological manufacturing processes differ fundamentally in their nature. Small-molecule production is often described as more straightforward "assembly line" chemistry: defined reactions converting known chemicals into a product. These processes are typically carried out in steel or glass reactors, sometimes allowing continuous flow chemistry, and tend to be more easily scalable and predictable. Biological manufacturing is far more complex – described as "more art than assembly line" – because it relies on living cells to produce the product. Bioprocesses demand very tight environmental control (sterility, precise pH, oxygen, etc.), and small deviations can dramatically impact yield or quality. Also, biologic products (like proteins) are much larger and sensitive molecules, requiring gentle handling and refrigeration; they cannot be sterilized by heat or filtration in final form, so the entire process must be aseptic. In contrast, many small molecules can undergo final sterilization (if needed) by filtration or heat. The equipment also differs: chemical processes may involve high temperatures, pressures, and solvents (sometimes in explosion-proof facilities), whereas biologics are usually aqueous, moderate conditions but require cleanroom environments. Small-molecule facilities might focus on optimizing throughput of reactions and chemical yield, while biologics facilities focus on avoiding contamination and maintaining cell viability. Another nuance is batch size and scale: a single biologics batch (e.g., a 10,000 L bioreactor) might produce a few kilograms of product, whereas a single chemical batch in a similar volume reactor could yield hundreds of kilograms of small-molecule API. Thus, biologics often have many more process steps in purification to remove impurities (host cell proteins, DNA, etc.), whereas small molecules often have fewer but still require high purity (removal of residual solvents, byproducts). Despite differences, both types increasingly use similar modern tools: for example, continuous processing and PAT, though more established in small molecule, are being adapted for biologics as well (e.g., continuous perfusion bioreactors and continuous chromatography).

EXAMPLES:
An illustrative example for small molecules is Janssen’s switch to continuous manufacturing for a drug like Prezista: they implemented an integrated continuous production line with real-time monitoring, resulting in faster production and real-time release of product (minimizing lab testing delays). For biologics, Amgen’s Next-Gen Biomanufacturing facility is often cited – it uses single-use bioreactors and flexible equipment, allowing rapid reconfiguration of processes and scale-up of different products in the same plant. In practice, a biologics operator might use a DeltaV DCS system to control a bioreactor, with PAT analyzers (e.g., for glucose, lactate) feeding data to adjust feed rates automatically to maximize cell growth. Meanwhile, a small-molecule plant may use PAT like online NIR to monitor a reaction’s completion and trigger the next step without waiting for off-line lab results, thereby reducing cycle time. These examples show how both sectors leverage technology to ensure consistent manufacturing. Notably, in one case a manufacturer of a monoclonal antibody reported that adopting single-use bioreactors and continuous processing increased their batch output per year by over 100%, demonstrating the power of process innovation.
process_steps.vision_statement: Automated, intelligent and integrated processes drive efficiency and continuous improvement throughout process and product lifecycle.
process_steps.interfaces_text:
Production Planning & Scheduling: Receives production orders and schedules.
Supply Chain Management (SCM): For intra-plant logistics until handover to production.
Quality Control (QC): For IPC sampling, lab analysis (though aiming to reduce with inline testing), and batch release data.
Quality Assurance (QA): For MBR compliance, deviation management, and batch release oversight.
Engineering (GFE) / Automation: For equipment integration, sensor implementation, and automation solutions.
IT & GBS: For MES, LIMS, ERP integration, data platforms (Dataland), and MBR system support.
Innovation Unit Development (IU Dev): For seamless drug product knowledge transfer, DoE, and FMEA.
Maintenance: For equipment status and troubleshooting (supported by AR).
process_steps.what_is_actually_done:
Conducting commercial production, test and technical batches, and new product introductions. Creating, managing, and executing digitally supported MBRs and master recipes, aiming for standardization, automated generation from templates, and a harmonized MBR library (M04). Automatically collecting and transferring data to/from equipment and IPC devices, ensuring vertical integration and harmonized data definitions (e.g., for draw, sample, analyze procedures) (M06). Monitoring process parameters in real-time using inline measurements and sensors, with dashboards and alerts for negative trends to enable early reaction and correction (M03). Using data simulation, AI, and machine learning to detect anomalies, identify potential process problems or equipment issues proactively during production, and support incident tackling (M08). Performing IPCs and leveraging PAT. Utilizing a unified data source/platform for IU Dev and Operations to assess process risks, define control strategies (FMEA, CSS), monitor product/process robustness, and enable a feedback loop from production to development (M05). Using AR for guiding operators/mechanics in tasks like troubleshooting, process execution (e.g., complex changeovers), setup, and identifying errors (M09). Collecting data relevant for batch release from the execution process (M07 related activities). Managing intra-plant logistics (including material introduction to lines) and packaging operations.

In chemical (small-molecule) manufacturing, typical actions include measuring and dispensing raw materials, carrying out chemical reactions in reactors, monitoring temperature, pressure, and reaction progress, then performing separations (distillation, filtration) and purification (crystallization, chromatography) to isolate the API. After the API is made, it may be formulated into tablets, capsules, etc., involving mixing with excipients, granulation, pressing, and coating in the case of solid doses. For biologics, the process starts with cell culture (e.g., growing genetically engineered CHO cells or E. coli in a series of bioreactors). Operators or automation systems prepare growth media, inoculate bioreactors, and maintain optimal conditions (pH, dissolved oxygen, nutrients) over days or weeks. They then harvest the product (e.g., by centrifugation or filtration to separate cells) and run a cascade of purification steps such as protein A affinity chromatography, ultrafiltration/diafiltration, and sterile filtration to achieve the desired purity. All along, in-process samples are taken and tested (for potency, purity, bioburden, etc.) to ensure the process is on track. Both types of manufacturing end with a product that must be filled/finished (for biologics, often into vials or syringes under aseptic conditions; for small molecules, into tablets, capsules, or bulk APIs in containers). Every action is documented in batch records, and deviations trigger investigations.
process_steps.pain_points:
System breaks and lack of harmonization in MBR design and execution across sites.
Manual data transfer between systems and equipment; lack of fully vertical integration.
Delayed identification and reaction to negative process trends or anomalies.
High manual effort in launches and transfers due to fragmented drug product knowledge.
Lack of a unified data source between IU Dev and Operations for product knowledge.
Difficulties in accessing real-time, comprehensive data for troubleshooting and process optimization.
Inconsistent IPC practices and data collection.
Limited use of PAT and inline measurements, leading to reliance on time-consuming lab analytics.
Suboptimal equipment utilization due to unforeseen failures or disturbances.
Language differences and varying factory designs hindering process harmonization.
High effort for MBR creation and review; lack of automated generation and validation.

process_steps.name: 05 | PRODUCT, SITE, PROCESS DATA USAGE
process_steps.step_description: At every level – product, site, and process – data is a critical asset in modern pharmaceutical manufacturing. This step refers to how data is collected, analyzed, and utilized to drive decision-making and continuous improvement. It is technical in the sense of data infrastructure (databases, historians, analytics) and process-focused in using that data to ensure processes remain in control and products meet quality standards. Data usage spans from real-time process control data (temperatures, pressures, analytical readings) to batch records and quality test results, to site-level KPIs (like overall equipment effectiveness, yield trends). Integrating these data streams allows for holistic visibility and enables advanced approaches like Continued Process Verification (CPV) and operational excellence initiatives.
process_steps.raw_content:
TECHNOLOGIES:
A range of digital technologies facilitate comprehensive data use. Manufacturing Execution Systems (MES) serve as a backbone by digitally capturing batch execution data (e.g., process parameters, operator entries, deviations) in electronic batch records. Process historians, as mentioned, store high-frequency equipment and sensor data; these often interface directly with automation control systems to log data every few seconds. Advanced analytics software is then layered on top: for example, multivariate analysis tools can analyze combinations of process parameters to predict quality outcomes. Many companies employ statistical process control (SPC) software and systems for real-time monitoring – sending alerts if any parameter trends toward an alert or action limit. AI and machine learning are increasingly applied: models might be trained on historical batches to predict yield or identify which process parameters most influence product quality. This can help in both trouble-shooting and in optimizing processes (e.g., reducing cycle time without affecting quality). Data infrastructure is also evolving – some pharma manufacturers are building data lakes or centralized data platforms that unify data from multiple sites, enabling cross-site comparisons and global process improvement programs. In terms of specific methodologies, CPV programs are now standard, where each product’s data is continually analyzed post-approval to ensure the process remains in a state of control. Real-time release testing (enabled by PAT and robust process data) is another practice: if process data prove the product quality within specs, some final tests can be skipped or minimized. Additionally, visualization and reporting tools (like Tableau or custom operational dashboards) are used by site management to slice and dice production data, which informs decisions on where to focus improvements.

DIFFERENCES:
While both small-molecule and biotech manufacturing rely on data, the types of data and their usage can differ. In small-molecule production, data often relate to physical parameters of chemical reactions and solid dosage formulation – such as reaction completion percentages, impurity levels, tablet hardness, etc. These processes might generate large datasets when PAT is used (e.g., spectroscopic readings) but are sometimes simpler (e.g., end-of-batch assay and yield). Biologics processes are typically monitored with even more extensive data due to the complexity of living systems – dozens of parameters (pH, DO, CO2, glucose, cell density, viability, etc.) are tracked throughout a culture, and advanced analyzers (like automatic cell counters or metabolic analyzers) feed data back. The product quality data set is also complex (e.g., a monoclonal antibody has many attributes like glycosylation patterns, which are monitored). Hence, biologics manufacturers often employ sophisticated data analytics to understand and reduce variability; for instance, they might use multivariate models to ensure a consistent glycosylation profile by correlating it with subtle shifts in culture conditions. Another difference is scale of data: a single biotech batch runtime may produce a massive amount of sensor data over several weeks, whereas a typical small-molecule batch (maybe a few hours reaction) yields less time-series data but possibly more discrete QC data points per batch. Regulatory expectations for data monitoring apply to both, but biologics (being more variable) often demand a more aggressive CPV program with more frequent data analysis to assure stability. In small-molecule manufacturing, especially with continuous processes, data usage has grown (continuous processes generate continuous data streams, requiring real-time analytics). In summary, both domains fully embrace data-driven manufacturing, but biologics might need a finer comb through data to ensure consistency of these complex molecules, whereas small-molecule production benefits from data mainly to tighten efficiency and yield of well-characterized processes.

EXAMPLES:
For example, one large biotech company implemented a multivariate analysis on their bioreactor data and discovered that slight variations in a nutrient feed rate were correlating with a drop in product potency. By adjusting their feed control (guided by the data model), they were able to reduce batch-to-batch variability by ~50%. In the small-molecule arena, a tablet manufacturing site used statistical analysis of process data from their press and coater to identify that most of their deviations were occurring during a specific humidity range. They installed additional humidity controls and virtually eliminated those deviations, as shown by subsequent data trending. Another illustrative case is continued process verification: one generic drug manufacturer set up a CPV system to aggregate all batch data and quality results for a new product. Within the first year, the CPV analysis flagged a slow drift in an assay potency trending downward. The team intervened and found slight wear in a mixer blade was causing less uniform mixing. This preemptive catch, driven by data, prevented future out-of-specification batches. On a site level, companies like Pfizer have talked about using centralized data dashboards across their global manufacturing network: each site’s output, quality metrics, and even energy usage are tracked, allowing best practices to be shared and any performance anomalies to be quickly spotted by corporate teams. These examples demonstrate that systematic data use – from granular process sensor data up to plant-wide metrics – is now integral to pharma manufacturing, enabling smarter, proactive operations.
process_steps.vision_statement: Our process & product data are easily accessible by the right person at the right time with the right quality and enables us to generate insights for production robustness & performance.
process_steps.interfaces_text:
Manufacturing Processes: Source of production data (IPC, equipment data, batch records).
Quality Control (QC): Lab data, IPC data, data for deviation management.
Quality Assurance (QA): Data for CPV, deviation/CAPA management, audit preparation, approval documents.
Innovation Unit Development (IU Dev): For data exchange related to launches, transfers, process robustness, and feedback for product/process development.
IT & GBS: For data platforms (Dataland, GDTS), MES, LIMS, data governance, and AI tool support.
Data Science Teams: For advanced analytics, process modeling, and AI-driven insights.
Regulatory Affairs (RA): For automated creation of registration documents.
Corporate Quality Audits & Inspection: For automated audit preparation.
process_steps.what_is_actually_done:
Making production data (including data science insights, discrepancy management, data integrity information, and master batch records) available and usable. Using real-time data for Continuous Process Verification (CPV) and assessing 'Prozessrobustheit' (process robustness). Establishing feedback loops from manufacturing to IU (Innovation Unit Development) for continuous improvement. Using AI and real-time data pools to speed up deviation investigations and CAPA management, including seamless product traceability and automated summary creation (M16). Providing self-service data platforms (connected to Dataland) to enable business units to perform their own data analyses and evaluations, ensuring transparency of process, equipment, and product data (M17). Automatically preparing documentation for audits using production and quality data to reduce preparation time (M18). Using AI to automatically generate approval documents, such as registration documents, based on development and production data (MBRs, SOPs, etc.) (M19). Comparing IPC, lab data, and other process data across internal sites and CMOs for continuous process verification (Multi-Site-CPV), batch comparison, troubleshooting, and process optimization, leveraging AI where applicable (M20).

In practice, pharmaceutical companies establish data collection systems throughout manufacturing. Process data from sensors and equipment are typically captured by a data historian system (for example, OSIsoft PI or Aspen InfoPlus21), which can store time-series data like a bioreactor’s temperature profile or a tablet press’s compression force readings. Batch-wise data (e.g., lot numbers, operator entries, test results) are recorded in MES and LIMS (Laboratory Information Management Systems). These data are then aggregated and analyzed. One key activity is Continued Process Verification – after process validation, companies continuously monitor critical process and quality parameters across batches. Engineers and quality teams review control charts and trends; if a drift or out-of-trend condition is detected, they investigate and correct before it becomes a deviation. Sites also compile Annual Product Reviews/Product Quality Reviews where data on all batches in the year, all deviations, and lab results are analyzed to identify improvements or ensure consistent quality. On the production floor, data from PAT instruments might be fed into control algorithms – for example, if a NIR sensor in a mixer detects the blend uniformity has reached the target, the system can end the blending step, using data for real-time control. Operators and managers use dashboards that visualize data like current batch status, equipment utilization, and yield in real time. At the site level, data is used for performance management – tracking metrics like batch cycle times, downtime reasons, and right-first-time batch execution rate. All these actions ensure that data isn't just collected but actively used to maintain a state of control and drive improvement.
process_steps.pain_points:
Lack of equipment standards, including interface definitions for data exchange.
No unified system for data analysis; data often siloed.
Uncertainty regarding data storage locations and inconsistent data quality.
Difficulties in transferring data smoothly from launch to routine production phases.
Limited mobile availability of data.
Missing batch context for sensor trend data, hindering analysis.
Process modeling and mining are not yet fully utilized.
CPV monitoring relies heavily on lab data from LIMS instead of real-time IPC/process data.
Data, knowledge, and best-practice sharing across sites is manual or non-existent.
Master data processes are not well-established to ensure high-quality master data.
Limited use of AI for data-driven support and insights.
Lack of a digital data backbone for shared use of batch data between Product Development (IU) and Product Lifecycle Management (HPS).
Missing tools for self-service data access and analysis by business users.
Manual and time-consuming preparation of audit and approval documents.
Inefficient deviation and CAPA management due to manual data collection and analysis.

process_steps.name: 06 | WORKPLACE & OPERATOR ASSISTANCE
process_steps.step_description: This aspect focuses on the human element in pharmaceutical manufacturing – the tools and processes in place to assist operators and technicians in performing their work accurately, efficiently, and safely. Even with high levels of automation, human operators are critical in tasks like equipment setup, maintenance, oversight of batches, and response to alarms or anomalies. Workplace and operator assistance encompasses training programs, ergonomic and safety measures, and digital aids that guide and support workers on the shop floor. Technically, it's about interfacing humans with complex processes and technology (often through user-friendly software or devices), and process-wise, it's about ensuring that people can perform their tasks right-first-time with minimal errors.
process_steps.raw_content:
TECHNOLOGIES:
A variety of emerging technologies are enhancing operator assistance. Augmented Reality (AR) and Virtual Reality (VR) are at the forefront: AR, using devices like Microsoft HoloLens or tablets, can overlay digital information onto the operator’s field of view. This is used for on-the-job guidance and has been shown to reduce errors and training time. VR is used for immersive training modules – for example, Pfizer has used VR to accelerate training for COVID-19 vaccine production, reportedly cutting training time by 40%. Another technology is electronic logbooks and voice-assisted documentation – operators can use speech recognition to log activities hands-free, which is particularly helpful when fully gowned or when sterility must be maintained. Manufacturing Execution Systems often have user interfaces tailored for operators, with touchscreens at workstations that show the production steps required and capture their inputs (e.g., confirming a weight or scanning an equipment ID). In terms of robotics, cobots (collaborative robots) are being deployed to work alongside humans, taking over repetitive or precision tasks such as picking and placing vials on a fill line or performing complex aseptic manipulations behind isolator glass. These robots reduce manual workload and contamination risk while the operator supervises. Digital twin and simulation tools also assist planners and operators in understanding the workflow – for instance, an operator can preview a process change in a simulated environment to understand new procedures before actual implementation. All these technologies aim to augment human capabilities: they provide immediate access to information (like an AR overlay of an SOP), reduce cognitive load by guiding sequential steps, and act as a safeguard against mistakes (e.g., scanning a barcode to ensure the correct ingredient is added).

DIFFERENCES:
The nature of operator assistance can differ between chemical and biological manufacturing environments due to differences in their operational context. In biologics, operators often work in cleanrooms with full gowning (coveralls, masks, gloves) to maintain sterility, which can impede communication and access to reference materials. Therefore, hands-free and visual guidance tools (like AR glasses or heads-up displays) provide a big advantage – allowing an operator to, say, see instructions without touching paper. Training in aseptic technique is also crucial and often supplemented by VR to simulate contamination scenarios. Biotech operators may also require more aid in monitoring because processes run for days; control rooms with advanced HMI (human-machine interfaces) aggregate bioreactor data, and alarm systems help a small team oversee many tanks. Small-molecule operators, particularly in API plants, might deal more with chemical safety hazards (toxicity, flammability). Thus, their assistance tools often emphasize safety – for example, sensors and wearable devices might monitor exposure levels to solvents, and VR training might focus on emergency responses to chemical spills or reactor incidents. Physical assistance is another aspect: in a small-molecule API plant, an operator might use drum lifters or even powered exoskeletons to handle heavy raw material bags, whereas in a biologics plant, the materials are usually liquid and moved with pumps, so the focus is more on sterile connections which are aided by things like single-use sterile connectors and welding tools (with training to use them properly). However, both domains share many operator assistance strategies: both use MES-guided instructions to minimize human error, both invest in continuous training (like simulated batch run exercises), and both are starting to use AR/VR. The difference lies mostly in the content – e.g., AR might show an operator how to assemble a chromatography column in biotech versus how to configure a reactor charging system in a chemical plant. Finally, the regulatory focus on human performance is the same: any human error can cause deviations, so whether it’s tablet manufacturing or biologics, companies support their operators with tools that catch errors (barcode verification, checklists) and simplify compliance (auto-recording actions, etc.).

EXAMPLES:
A notable example of operator assistance is from a leading pharma company that implemented an AR-based training and guidance system (PTC’s Vuforia Expert Capture). They reported that the technology helped standardize procedures across their sites: one result was more consistent line clearance processes, preventing mistakes and saving an estimated $27 million per factory by avoiding production downtime and scrap. Another example: Novartis has used HoloLens AR for equipment maintenance – technicians following holographic step-by-step guides reduced their machine downtime during changeovers and maintenance by double-digit percentages. On the VR side, Merck has experimented with VR for aseptic training, letting operators virtually practice interventions in an isolator without risking contamination in real life; this improved competence and confidence once they performed the actual task. In terms of robotics aiding operators, companies like Johnson & Johnson have deployed collaborative robots in packaging lines to handle intricate assembly tasks, allowing operators to shift to oversight roles. In a small-molecule plant scenario, a team introduced a voice-operated system for logging batch steps (using speech recognition to fill electronic log entries). Operators found this reduced distraction and paperwork mid-process, leading to fewer missed documentation steps. These examples reflect a trend: the pharma industry is embracing technologies to assist the workforce – not replacing humans, but enabling them to work smarter, safer, and with greater precision in both chemical and biotech production settings.
process_steps.vision_statement: We empower employees to upskill themselves independently and efficiently by easy access to relevant knowledge and digitally supported learning processes
process_steps.interfaces_text:
Human Resources (HR): For onboarding processes, training programs, and qualification management (e.g., BI University).
Quality Assurance (QA): For SOP management, training records, GMP compliance, and supplier qualification.
Manufacturing Processes: Operators interact with these systems during their daily work.
IT & GBS: For digital tool implementation (AR/VR, AI assistants, translation tools, knowledge platforms, MES interfaces like Veeva Vault).
Engineering (GFE): For technical documentation and equipment-related knowledge.

process_steps.what_is_actually_done:
Providing tools and processes for managing and accessing knowledge, including SOPs, MBRs, technical documentation, and training materials. Managing employee qualifications and providing training, including shift planning and leveraging digital tools like AR/VR. Providing clear guidance for manufacturing operations through SOPs, MBRs, etc. Implementing automated process and equipment alerts for exception-based intervention. Implementing digital onboarding plans with role-based assignment of training and SOPs, flexible interfaces for individual plan adjustment, and digital signatures (M21). Providing real-time, overarching translation for manufacturing information to overcome language barriers, potentially integrated into systems like MES or via tools like Copilot (M22). Establishing a global database or dashboard for reliable identification of supplier qualification data (e.g., which raw/packaging material is qualified for which product at which site) (M23). Providing AI-powered assistance (e.g., Process CoPilot, Q&A tools) for operators to quickly find information in SOPs/MBRs, understand processes, get context-sensitive support, and manage incidents (M24). Using AI to support knowledge management through tools like AI-powered Q&A for SOPs, GenAI for finding answers, digital logbooks, and SOP knowledge graphs for visualizing hierarchies and contexts (M25).

On the ground, companies undertake numerous actions to support their workforce. Comprehensive training is foundational – new operators undergo training on SOPs, equipment operation, safety protocols, and aseptic techniques (for sterile operations). Increasingly, this training uses simulations and VR; for instance, VR modules can let trainees practice handling a hazardous chemical spill or gowning for a cleanroom in a risk-free virtual environment. When operators are at work, they often follow standard operating procedures which are now frequently delivered via digital devices (tablets or smart glasses) rather than paper binders. A common practice is to equip operators with electronic work instructions that can include images or even augmented reality overlays; for example, during a machine setup, an AR device might highlight which valve to turn or which part to replace, step by step. Operators also perform checks and data entries, which are made easier with barcode scanners (to verify materials), and handheld devices to record data without transcribing later. Another facet is safety and ergonomics: companies provide assistive devices like hoists or even collaborative robots to help lift heavy containers, reducing physical strain. In sterile or potent compound environments, specialized equipment (isolators, gloveboxes, or even exoskeletons with air supply) assist operators in doing their tasks without exposure. Additionally, communication tools are provided – for example, an operator encountering a problem can use a connected headset to call a remote specialist who sees their view via a camera (remote assist). This proved invaluable during times like the pandemic, enabling expert guidance without travel.

process_steps.name: 04 | EQUIPMENT & AUTOMATION LIFECYCLE PROCESS
process_steps.step_description: Pharmaceutical manufacturing equipment and automation systems have a regulated lifecycle that spans selection, qualification, operation, maintenance, and eventual decommissioning. This process ensures that every machine or control system used in production is reliable, performs as intended, and remains in a validated state throughout its use. The lifecycle is technical, involving engineering and quality assurance at every phase: from design and factory acceptance testing, to installation and validation in the plant, through ongoing calibration and preventive maintenance, and finally upgrades or retirement. Automation (software and control hardware) follows a similar lifecycle with an added layer of computerized system validation to comply with data integrity and GMP requirements.
process_steps.raw_content:
TECHNOLOGIES:
Managing equipment and automation over its lifecycle increasingly relies on digital tools. Calibration management software automatically tracks when each instrument (e.g., pressure gauge, pH meter) is due for calibration and can even trigger work orders and document the results electronically. IoT sensors and Asset Performance Management platforms are used for predictive maintenance – for example, vibration or temperature sensors on a mixer can signal an impending bearing failure, allowing maintenance to be scheduled just in time. Advanced analytics (sometimes AI-based) analyze equipment data to predict failures; a digital predictive maintenance approach can significantly reduce unplanned downtime and batch losses. Automation systems themselves use redundancy and self-diagnostics – modern bioreactors controllers or packaging line PLCs often have built-in alarms that notify staff if a parameter drifts or a component is failing. During the operational life, electronic change management systems (often part of quality management software) help track any changes to equipment or software, enforcing approvals and documentation. For example, if a company needs to update a PLC’s firmware, the change control system ensures the update is tested and approved by quality, and that the system is re-validated. Additionally, simulation and digital twin technologies can model equipment performance; before making a change, engineers might simulate the impact on the process. Augmented reality is also emerging here: an engineer with AR glasses can pull up an overlay of a machine’s maintenance history or be guided in a repair procedure, improving accuracy and speed. By leveraging these technologies, firms maintain equipment in a state of control and extend its life while complying with the stringent regulatory expectations.

DIFFERENCES:
Small-molecule and biologics plants share the core principles of equipment lifecycle management, but there are a few distinctions in focus. Biologics manufacturing often has more emphasis on sterile boundary and environmental control equipment – e.g., cleanroom HVAC systems, HEPA filters, sterilizing-grade filters – which all require regular integrity testing and replacement. Equipment in biologics (like bioreactors, ultrafiltration skids) may see more frequent clean/sterilize cycles, which can cause wear; thus, components like seals and gaskets might be replaced more often and tracked closely. Also, because biologics processes are sensitive, there is heavy use of sensors (pH, DO, CO2, cell density monitors) that need frequent calibration (sometimes before each batch). Small-molecule plants might focus more on equipment performance under harsh conditions (e.g., a reactor’s ability to handle corrosive chemicals or high pressure), so the maintenance might involve material integrity checks (ensuring no corrosion or metal fatigue). Another difference is the adoption of single-use equipment in biologics: the lifecycle for disposables is short (single batch), but the supporting equipment (like single-use bioreactor shells and control units) must be maintained and qualified in a way that ensures each new disposable integration is seamless. Single-use components shift some lifecycle burden to the supply chain (qualifying suppliers and incoming lots of bags), rather than maintenance of steel tanks, changing the nature of ‘equipment’ management. In small-molecule (especially traditional API synthesis), equipment tends to be fixed and long-lived (reactors in use for decades), so there’s a strong focus on periodic requalification and retrofitting older systems with new automation as needed. Biotech facilities, being newer, often incorporate more advanced automation from the start (distributed control systems with electronic batch records inbuilt), whereas some older pharma API plants might still have more manual or analog processes that are gradually being automated. Regulatory expectations compel both types of facilities to keep detailed records; for example, any equipment that impacts product quality in either type must show a traceable history of calibration and maintenance. Ultimately, the life-cycle process is about guaranteeing that whether it's a chemical reactor or a bioreactor, a tablet press or an aseptic filler, it consistently performs as intended every time it’s used.

EXAMPLES:
A concrete example: a pharmaceutical company implemented a predictive maintenance program on its tablet coating machines by installing vibration and motor current sensors. This led to early detection of motor wear; unplanned downtime was reduced by 30% as maintenance could be done in planned windows, preventing coating batch failures. Another example is in biotech: a major vaccine producer uses an electronic calibration management system for all critical instruments (thermometers, pressure gauges, etc.), ensuring no instrument exceeds its calibration due date – this has practically eliminated batch deviations caused by out-of-calibration equipment. In the realm of automation, companies follow GAMP5 guidelines. For instance, when upgrading a bioreactor control software, one firm created a digital twin of the process to test the new control logic virtually before implementation, avoiding disruption. Also, the importance of lifecycle management was highlighted when the industry faced the Windows XP to Windows 10 transition for control systems: many pharma sites had to replace or upgrade automation hardware and software, doing extensive re-validation. Those with good lifecycle practices and vendor support handled this smoothly, while others faced compliance risks with aging systems. Across both small and large molecule production, such examples underscore proactive lifecycle management: by continuously monitoring asset health and upgrading technology in a controlled manner, pharma manufacturers prevent costly downtime and ensure consistent product quality.
process_steps.vision_statement: Throughout the life-cycle we have transparency on all equipment related data enabling efficient manufacturing and cross-functional decision making.
process_steps.interfaces_text:
Engineering (GFE): For equipment design, URS, factory planning, automation solutions, and maintenance planning.
IT: For database implementation, tracking systems, and data integration.
Maintenance: For equipment history, calibration status, and maintenance procedures.
Quality Assurance (QA): For qualification documentation, equipment standards, and validation.
Production Planning & Scheduling: For information on equipment availability and status.
Manufacturing Processes: For actual usage of equipment and feedback on performance.
Procurement: For new equipment purchases and supplier selection based on standards.
Supply Chain Management (SCM): Potentially for tracking of large containers or inter-factory equipment movements.
process_steps.what_is_actually_done:
Defining user requirements specifications (URS), technical specifications (TS), and factory planning for operating equipment and automation solutions. Managing the process of how equipment is used and re-used throughout its lifecycle. Implementing systems (e.g., geo-localization with trackers, NFC/RFID, online dashboards) to provide real-time transparency on the location and status (e.g., clean, calibrated, in use) of movable equipment and format parts. This includes automated identification and cross-checks (M14). Establishing and maintaining a globally accessible database of all production equipment, including performance data, qualification documents (URS, IQ, OQ, PQ), modification history, and standards. This supports equipment standardization, facilitates transfers/launches, and enables AI-assisted information retrieval (M15). Driving standardization of equipment, vendors (where feasible), and qualification procedures to reduce variability and effort.

ACTIONS:
Key actions in the equipment lifecycle start with defining user requirements and design specifications when new equipment is procured or built. Upon arrival, machines undergo Installation Qualification (IQ) to verify they are installed correctly, Operational Qualification (OQ) to ensure they function as expected across intended operating ranges, and Performance Qualification (PQ) to confirm they consistently produce acceptable product under real conditions. Automation systems (like a DCS or MES) are validated according to GAMP5 guidelines – including verifying software functions and securing data (21 CFR Part 11 compliance). During production, a robust maintenance program is in place: equipment is regularly inspected, lubricated, and parts replaced on schedules, and instruments are calibrated at defined intervals to maintain accuracy. These tasks are often managed via a computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) or enterprise asset management module (for instance, many use SAP PM or Maximo to schedule and record maintenance and calibration events). If a sensor drifts out of calibration or a part shows wear, it is repaired and then the equipment may require requalification to ensure it still meets specifications. Change control procedures govern any modifications: even a minor software update or equipment change must be assessed for impact, tested, and documented to keep the system in a validated state. Finally, as equipment ages or technology advances, companies plan for upgrades or replacements (obsolescence management); this might involve running new and old systems in parallel during validation of the new, to ensure no disruption. Throughout the lifecycle, documentation is maintained (like equipment logs, validation reports, calibration certificates) to satisfy regulators that the equipment is fit for use at all times.

process_steps.name: 03 | CHANGE OVERS
process_steps.step_description: Changeover is the transition process of switching a production line or equipment from producing one product (or batch) to another. In pharmaceuticals, changeovers are critical junctures that involve thorough cleaning, setup changes, and documentation to prevent cross-contamination and ensure the next product’s quality. This step is technical and procedure-heavy: it includes everything from cleaning or replacing product contact parts, to recalibrating equipment if needed, to resetting electronic recipes for the new product. Efficient changeovers are essential for multi-product facilities to maintain high utilization, but they must be executed with meticulous care due to regulatory requirements (cleaning validation, line clearance by QA) and product safety considerations.
process_steps.raw_content:
TECHNOLOGIES:
Several technologies and practices help streamline and error-proof changeovers. Single-use technology, especially prevalent in biologics, has been a game-changer – by eliminating the cleaning step, changeover times can drop dramatically, enabling more batches per year. For example, pre-irradiated single-use assemblies can be swapped in within hours, whereas cleaning stainless steel tanks could take days. Automated CIP/SIP systems are employed in traditional equipment to ensure cleaning is thorough and reproducible; these systems are often validated to run optimized cleaning recipes, and they can be monitored via conductivity, TOC (total organic carbon), or bioburden sensors to confirm effectiveness. Electronic batch record systems (MES) aid changeovers by providing step-by-step instructions and checklists, ensuring that no step (like a valve setting or filter change) is missed and logging completion digitally. Lean manufacturing techniques such as SMED (Single-Minute Exchange of Die) are also applied – for instance, teams analyze the changeover workflow to move some steps offline or in parallel, thus shortening the critical path. Digital tools and even Augmented Reality are starting to assist here: an operator wearing AR glasses can be guided visually through each cleaning and setup step, reducing reliance on memory and paper instructions. This was demonstrated by a top pharma company using AR for line clearance – the system provided visual cues to ensure every part was cleaned and cleared, which cut down errors and material scrap (previously, manual SOPs led to about 10% of yield being scrapped due to mistakes during changeover). Overall, technology is making changeovers faster and more foolproof, from automation that handles cleaning, to sensors that verify equipment cleanliness, to software that guides and records the entire process.

DIFFERENCES:
In small-molecule production, changeovers primarily focus on removing chemical residues and any remaining dosage units of the previous product. The cleaning may involve flushing reactors or equipment with solvents and cleaning agents that dissolve or carry away the active ingredients, and these processes are often easier to automate due to the robust nature of equipment (though potent compounds may require specialized handling to protect operators). Biologics changeovers are often more involved because of the need for absolute sterility and removal of living contaminants. A bioreactor changeover might include not just cleaning but also sterilization of the vessel and flow paths to kill any cells or microbes from the prior run. Bioprocess equipment often has more complex internal tubing and filters, requiring careful CIP techniques or complete replacement with single-use assemblies. Moreover, biologics facilities sometimes dedicate equipment to a product to avoid cross-contamination (especially for products like live virus vaccines where traces could be dangerous), whereas small-molecule facilities more commonly run different products on the same equipment with thorough cleaning. Single-use systems have made a particularly big impact in biologics: because disposables remove cross-contact, multi-product biologics plants became much more feasible, with changeovers measured in hours instead of days. In contrast, single-use is less applicable in large-scale chemical synthesis (due to solvents and reaction conditions that disposable plastic bags can’t handle), so chemical plants rely on efficient cleaning and maybe dedicated pipelines to prevent cross-contamination. Another difference is that biologics changeovers must often consider bio-safety (decontaminating any live organisms, including air handling systems as needed), while chemical changeovers focus on avoiding mix-ups and ensuring no active ingredient carryover beyond acceptable trace levels. Despite these differences, both sectors treat changeovers as critical operations with no compromise on cleaning standards, and both increasingly use data and tech to optimize the turnaround time.

EXAMPLES:
One example in biologics: Lonza, a contract manufacturer, has implemented single-use bioprocessing suites which allow them to switch between making different biotherapeutics in a matter of hours or a couple of days, whereas traditional stainless steel suites might need a week or more for full cleaning and sterilization. This agility was particularly useful when manufacturers had to rapidly change production lines to produce COVID-19 vaccines. In small molecule manufacturing, an example comes from a tablet production facility that applied SMED principles – they pre-staged cleaning crews and used quick-connect fittings – and managed to cut their formulation line changeover from 8 hours to 4 hours, significantly increasing their throughput capacity. Another case study from a pharma company using AR for changeovers (line clearance) showed that by using AR overlays to guide operators, they not only reduced mistakes but also saved an estimated tens of millions of dollars per plant by preventing batch scrappage and reducing downtime. These examples highlight how innovations in changeover processes, whether procedural (lean methods) or technological (single-use systems, AR guidance), are boosting productivity in pharma while maintaining impeccable quality standards.
process_steps.vision_statement: We achieve minimal down times through transparent, automated and digital supported change overs.
process_steps.interfaces_text:

Manufacturing Processes: Precedes and follows the actual manufacturing of batches.
Quality Control (QC): For cleaning validation, release of cleaned equipment (though aiming for automation).
Quality Assurance (QA): Oversight of cleaning validation and changeover documentation.
Maintenance: Involved in equipment setup, adjustments, and ensuring equipment readiness.
Engineering (GFE) / Automation: For automation of settings, Digital Twin development for optimization.
IT: For systems supporting live status tracking, Digital Twins, and automated recipe loading.
process_steps.what_is_actually_done:
Performing the physical changeover process, including equipment set-up, cleaning (minor, major, cross-cleaning), sterilization, and conditioning of systems. Managing equipment ('Ausrüstung') and format parts required for changeovers. Using historical data, simulation (Digital Twin), and AI-supported operator guidance to analyze, optimize, and standardize changeover processes, including setup sequences and product sequence optimization (M10). Implementing automated testing (e.g., TOC analysis via inline sensors) and release procedures for cleaning processes, potentially with approval by exception (M11). Automatically loading recipes and machine settings onto equipment to reduce manual effort and errors (M12). Providing real-time visibility (e.g., via digital info boards) into the progress of changeover activities and any potential disruptions for operators, coaches, and team leads (M13).

Practically, a changeover begins as soon as one batch finishes. Operators remove any remaining materials of the previous run and perform cleaning operations. On traditional stainless-steel equipment, this means running Clean-in-Place (CIP) cycles with detergents or solvents, followed by rinse cycles and often Steam-in-Place (SIP) for sterilization (especially in biologics manufacturing). They then test rinse water or swab surfaces to ensure no residues (per validated cleaning limits) remain before approving the equipment for the next product. In facilities using single-use components, changeover actions involve discarding used bags, filters, and tubing and installing fresh pre-sterilized components – which simplifies cleaning, since the product contact surfaces are new for each batch. Operators also swap out machine parts if needed (for example, different size tablet press tooling or filling line format parts for different vial sizes). After physical changeover, there is a rigorous line clearance check: trained staff (often QA) inspect and document that no traces of the prior product (like rogue pills or labels) are present in the area. Finally, the equipment settings or automation recipes are loaded for the new product, and a test run or verification may be done before full production resumes.

Lack of real-time visibility into changeover progress and potential issues.

process_steps.name: 06 | QC DATA ANALYSIS AND TRENDING
process_steps.step_description: Our user-centric framework allows continuous & automated QC data analysis, supported by AI to identify patterns across the analytical panel
process_steps.vision_statement: Our user-centric framework allows continuous & automated QC data analysis, supported by AI to identify patterns across the analytical panel
process_steps.interfaces_text:
Result Generation, Evaluation & Release (QC05): For sourcing QC analytical data.
LIMS/LES/ERP (SAP QM): Primary sources for analytical and operational QC data.
Quality Event Systems (e.g., GoTrack, SCRA, RQA): For non-analytical data like deviations, supplier assessments. (QC26)
Manufacturing Systems (MES): For process parameters that might be correlated with QC trends.
Equipment Management Systems (QC07): For equipment availability and maintenance data. (QC26)
Management Reporting Systems / BI Platforms: For disseminating trend reports and dashboards. (QC25)
Quality Assurance (QA): For insights into product quality, process stability, and CAPA effectiveness.
process_steps.what_is_actually_done: Automatically link analytical data to predefined trending scenarios. Reduce manual steps currently performed in systems like GDTS (e.g., mapping). Serve as a prerequisite for predictive analytics (QC24 / USE CASE 27). Use predictive analytics to identify potential quality issues before they occur (proactive measures). Employ AI for correlating analytical results within a batch or across multiple batches of a product. Utilize AI for identifying trends, patterns, shifts, and for health checks of methods/equipment/labs. Support real-time trending based on actual data. Enable AI-assisted automated trending, report generation (CPV, PQR, MQR), and self-service analytics on GxP validated QC data pools (QC25 / USE CASE 26). Automate the trending and evaluation of available lab data (e.g., discrepancies, equipment availability) using AI. Provide timely notifications if patterns arise. Automatically assess products (SCRA), suppliers (Purchasing Assessments, RQA), etc., using this non-analytical data. Implement a unified trending approach for all quality events, including report generation (QC26 / USE CASE 28).
process_steps.pain_points:
No clear vision for trending; scattered approaches are used.
All trending activities involve many manual steps.
No connection of all equipment to systems; still relying on logbooks and several disparate systems.
It's not clear what should be shown with trending.
Trending is done in multiple systems with a lot of manual steps.
Systems are not user-friendly for data analysis.
Getting data easily is not possible; a lot of manual work is involved.
Six to seven different trending reports that still don't provide a holistic picture.
No connection/interface to equipment to have data ready for monitoring/long-term overview.
Only partial integration of equipment into a "data lake."
KPIs are measured but not used; no common QC KPIs.
CMO data: Client responsibility, not all data governed by BI.
Manual data trending, no central governance, or overarching guidance.
Even for critical attributes, global solutions are not available in a user-friendly way.
Manual steps in GDTS (e.g., mapping) for linking data to trending scenarios. (USE CASE 27)

process_steps.name: 03 | SAMPLING AND SAMPLE STORAGE
process_steps.step_description: Sampling, handling and storage activities are automated, traceable, and synchronized, with real-time visibility and efficient distribution
process_steps.vision_statement: Sampling, handling and storage activities are automated, traceable, and synchronized, with real-time visibility and efficient distribution
process_steps.interfaces_text:
Manufacturing Execution Systems (MES) / Production: For initiating sampling, sample labeling, and receiving sample status/IPC results. (QC10, QC12)
Laboratory Information Management Systems (LIMS) / SAP QM: For receiving sample data, managing test orders, and storing sampling documentation. (QC10, QC12)
Inventory Management Systems: For tracking sample locations and quantities. (QC09)
Equipment Management (QC07): For ensuring availability of sampling equipment.
Testing Preparation and Execution (QC04): For handover of samples for testing.
Asset Administration Shell: For live-tracking of batch status. (USE CASE 10)
process_steps.what_is_actually_done: Implement an automated system (e.g., using RFID, barcodes, cameras) for tracking samples throughout their lifecycle. Provide real-time tracking, location updates (including digital localization in fridges), and alerts for sample movement/status. Ensure proper sample conditions with guided workflows and trigger warnings if handled/stored incorrectly. Integrate with lab and inventory systems (QC09 / USE CASE 12). Implement paperless, electronic documentation for all sampling events. Ensure digital logging of sampling events, real-time data entry and validation. Integrate with existing documentation systems (SAP QM, MES) for secure storage and easy retrieval. Document all information on how a sample is handled, including temperature control and other live data (QC10 / USE CASE 11). Utilize automated storage systems to efficiently manage large volumes of samples. Implement intelligent storage with temperature and humidity control. Ensure storage is locked and accessible only with digital authorization (e.g., card reader) (QC11 / USE CASE 13). Develop a seamless interface between production (MES) and lab software (LIMS/SAP QM). Automate the process of sending samples for analysis, including sample transfer from production to lab. Enable real-time data synchronization, including sample status ('Live-Tracking' of Batch) and IPC result transfer. Support sampling/labeling in MES with data transfer to LIMS (QC12 / USE CASE 10).
process_steps.pain_points:
No clear approach for sample handover.
Difficulties in reconciliation of samples.
Unclear documentation location for sampling (Production vs. QC).
Lack of sample tracking, especially for temperature-controlled samples.
Manual paper-based and copy/paste processes for sampling documentation.
Sampling and labeling in MES, but data transfer to/from LIMS is problematic.
Difficulty identifying samples in freezers.
Inadequate sample tracking from sampling until disposal.
Operator needs to switch between multiple systems (and learn them).
Sampling documentation is often paper-based (SDI).
Qualification of sample takers needs to be verifiable by QC.
Different UIs for several software systems, high training effort, system breaks. (USE CASE 10)
Access for sample takers to SAP/QM often not given. (USE CASE 11)
Data integrity issues due to system breaks in manual data transfer. (USE CASE 11)

process_steps.name: 07 | QC EQUIPMENT READINESS
process_steps.step_description: We use standardized lab equipment, that is fully connected, while always having transparency on equipment related data and status to operate seamlessly

process_steps.interfaces_text:

Testing Preparation and Execution (QC04): To ensure equipment is ready for use and to block usage if not. (QC27)
Procurement/Finance: For Capex planning, purchasing, and supplier management. (QC28)
LIMS/Trackwise: For interfacing digital logbooks and maintenance data. (QC31)
SAP PM: As a potential central system for equipment management and maintenance. (QC27, QC31)
IT Systems: For IoT connectivity and data platforms. (QC30)
Validation Departments: For periodic reviews of validated systems/methods. (QC29)
External Suppliers/Maintenance Providers: For maintenance activities and data handover. (QC27)
process_steps.what_is_actually_done: Maintain a comprehensive digital database and logbook (e.g., SAP PM) for all equipment data (qualifications, calibrations, daily checks, history, maintenance, status). Provide a centralized equipment data repository with a traffic light system for current status. Block equipment usage if not ready. Optimize maintenance activities based on use cycles/historical data (AI-based). Enrich metadata in SAP/PM for harmonization (QC27 / USE CASE 31). Establish and govern global standards for lab equipment catalogue, assets tracking, purchase, replacement, and Capex planning. Implement process/system control points to check purchases against the standard equipment catalogue. Focus on standardized equipment across all sites (QC28 / USE CASE 32). Automate (or semi-automate initially) the periodic review for computer systems, equipment, methods, validation, and Excel files. Ensure the review considers all relevant data (events, deviations, changes, SLC docs). Evaluate for negative trends (QC29 / USE CASE 35). Use IoT for equipment connectivity, enabling real-time monitoring and data collection. Implement predictive maintenance, supported by AI, based on available data and usage. Predict equipment failures proactively. Flexibly connect EQs and solutions in a standardized way via an architectural connectivity layer (QC30 / USE CASE 34). Implement digital equipment logbooks interfaced with LIMS, Trackwise, etc. Digitalize paper checklists for lab equipment maintenance. Make all system-related tasks and statuses visible and checked by electronic systems (no stickers except ID on equipment). Enable paperless documentation and logbook entries for maintenance, with connected systems and mobile maintenance capabilities. Use predictive models (AI-driven) to forecast maintenance needs and enable proactive scheduling (QC31 / USE CASE 33). Establish a harmonized and centralized organization for QC maintenance activities, potentially starting semi-automated (USE CASE 36).

Equipment is not standardized.
Different equipment from different vendors requires multiple systems.
Different, non-standardized procedures for calibration and set-up of equipment.
No transparency on equipment status.
No central equipment inventory (status, calibration, etc.).
Manual periodic review for lab equipment.
No (physical) equipment standards.
No global (protocol) standard for equipment set-up.
No lab equipment database (e.g., available equipment in my lab).
No electronic handover of documentation from supplier to BI.
Business process for usage of SAP/PM not globally standardized.
GxP logbook for computerized systems (IT, Business, etc.) frontend not user-friendly.
Equipment information is not available in a harmonized, transparent system. (USE CASE 31)
Information required for planning lab activities, maintenance, etc., is time-consuming to obtain. (USE CASE 31)
No strong central governance on equipment purchases by sites against global standard catalogue. (USE CASE 32)
Potential for lost/mis-allocated Capex investments due to non-standard equipment purchases. (USE CASE 32)
Maintenance documentation is often paper-based. (QC31 / USE CASE 33)
